string: ACT I
SCENE I. Westminster Abbey.
Dead March. Enter the Funeral of KING HENRY the  Fifth, attended on by Dukes of BEDFORD, Regent of  France; GLOUCESTER, Protector; and EXETER, Earl of WARWICK, the BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, Heralds,  & c
BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to night!
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Comets, importing change of times and states,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Brandish your crystal tresses in the sky,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: And with them scourge the bad revolting stars
speaker: BEDFORD

string: That have consented unto Henry's death!
speaker: BEDFORD

string: King Henry the Fifth, too famous to live long!
speaker: BEDFORD

string: England ne'er lost a king of so much worth.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: England ne'er had a king until his time.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Virtue he had, deserving to command:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: His brandish'd sword did blind men with his beams:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: His arms spread wider than a dragon's wings;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: His sparking eyes, replete with wrathful fire,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: More dazzled and drove back his enemies
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Than mid-day sun fierce bent against their faces.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: What should I say? his deeds exceed all speech:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: He ne'er lift up his hand but conquered.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: EXETER
speaker: EXETER

string: We mourn in black: why mourn we not in blood?
speaker: EXETER

string: Henry is dead and never shall revive:
speaker: EXETER

string: Upon a wooden coffin we attend,
speaker: EXETER

string: And death's dishonourable victory
speaker: EXETER

string: We with our stately presence glorify,
speaker: EXETER

string: Like captives bound to a triumphant car.
speaker: EXETER

string: What! shall we curse the planets of mishap
speaker: EXETER

string: That plotted thus our glory's overthrow?
speaker: EXETER

string: Or shall we think the subtle-witted French
speaker: EXETER

string: Conjurers and sorcerers, that afraid of him
speaker: EXETER

string: By magic verses have contrived his end?
speaker: EXETER

string: BISHOP
speaker: EXETER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: He was a king bless'd of the King of kings.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Unto the French the dreadful judgement-day
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: So dreadful will not be as was his sight.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: The battles of the Lord of hosts he fought:
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: The church's prayers made him so prosperous.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: The church! where is it? Had not churchmen pray'd,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: His thread of life had not so soon decay'd:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: None do you like but an effeminate prince,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Whom, like a school-boy, you may over-awe.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Gloucester, whate'er we like, thou art protector
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: And lookest to command the prince and realm.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Thy wife is proud; she holdeth thee in awe,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: More than God or religious churchmen may.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Name not religion, for thou lovest the flesh,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And ne'er throughout the year to church thou go'st
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Except it be to pray against thy foes.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Cease, cease these jars and rest your minds in peace:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Let's to the altar: heralds, wait on us:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Instead of gold, we'll offer up our arms:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Since arms avail not now that Henry's dead.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Posterity, await for wretched years,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: When at their mothers' moist eyes babes shall suck,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Our isle be made a nourish of salt tears,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: And none but women left to wail the dead.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Henry the Fifth, thy ghost I invocate:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Prosper this realm, keep it from civil broils,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Combat with adverse planets in the heavens!
speaker: BEDFORD

string: A far more glorious star thy soul will make
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Than Julius Caesar or bright--
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Enter a Messenger
Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: My honourable lords, health to you all!
speaker: Messenger

string: Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,
speaker: Messenger

string: Of loss, of slaughter and discomfiture:
speaker: Messenger

string: Guienne, Champagne, Rheims, Orleans,
speaker: Messenger

string: Paris, Guysors, Poictiers, are all quite lost.
speaker: Messenger

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: What say'st thou, man, before dead Henry's corse?
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Speak softly, or the loss of those great towns
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Is Paris lost? is Rouen yielded up?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: If Henry were recall'd to life again,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: These news would cause him once more yield the ghost.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: EXETER
speaker: EXETER

string: How were they lost? what treachery was used?
speaker: EXETER

string: Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: No treachery; but want of men and money.
speaker: Messenger

string: Amongst the soldiers this is muttered,
speaker: Messenger

string: That here you maintain several factions,
speaker: Messenger

string: And whilst a field should be dispatch'd and fought,
speaker: Messenger

string: You are disputing of your generals:
speaker: Messenger

string: One would have lingering wars with little cost;
speaker: Messenger

string: Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings;
speaker: Messenger

string: A third thinks, without expense at all,
speaker: Messenger

string: By guileful fair words peace may be obtain'd.
speaker: Messenger

string: Awake, awake, English nobility!
speaker: Messenger

string: Let not sloth dim your horrors new-begot:
speaker: Messenger

string: Cropp'd are the flower-de-luces in your arms;
speaker: Messenger

string: Of England's coat one half is cut away.
speaker: Messenger

string: EXETER
speaker: EXETER

string: Were our tears wanting to this funeral,
speaker: EXETER

string: These tidings would call forth their flowing tides.
speaker: EXETER

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Me they concern; Regent I am of France.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Give me my steeled coat. I'll fight for France.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Away with these disgraceful wailing robes!
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Wounds will I lend the French instead of eyes,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: To weep their intermissive miseries.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Enter to them another Messenger
Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: Lords, view these letters full of bad mischance.
speaker: Messenger

string: France is revolted from the English quite,
speaker: Messenger

string: Except some petty towns of no import:
speaker: Messenger

string: The Dauphin Charles is crowned king of Rheims;
speaker: Messenger

string: The Bastard of Orleans with him is join'd;
speaker: Messenger

string: Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part;
speaker: Messenger

string: The Duke of Alencon flieth to his side.
speaker: Messenger

string: EXETER
speaker: EXETER

string: The Dauphin crowned king! all fly to him!
speaker: EXETER

string: O, whither shall we fly from this reproach?
speaker: EXETER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: We will not fly, but to our enemies' throats.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Bedford, if thou be slack, I'll fight it out.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Gloucester, why doubt'st thou of my forwardness?
speaker: BEDFORD

string: An army have I muster'd in my thoughts,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Wherewith already France is overrun.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Enter another Messenger
Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: My gracious lords, to add to your laments,
speaker: Messenger

string: Wherewith you now bedew King Henry's hearse,
speaker: Messenger

string: I must inform you of a dismal fight
speaker: Messenger

string: Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.
speaker: Messenger

string: BISHOP
speaker: Messenger

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: What! wherein Talbot overcame? is't so?
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: O, no; wherein Lord Talbot was o'erthrown:
speaker: Messenger

string: The circumstance I'll tell you more at large.
speaker: Messenger

string: The tenth of August last this dreadful lord,
speaker: Messenger

string: Retiring from the siege of Orleans,
speaker: Messenger

string: Having full scarce six thousand in his troop.
speaker: Messenger

string: By three and twenty thousand of the French
speaker: Messenger

string: Was round encompassed and set upon.
speaker: Messenger

string: No leisure had he to enrank his men;
speaker: Messenger

string: He wanted pikes to set before his archers;
speaker: Messenger

string: Instead whereof sharp stakes pluck'd out of hedges
speaker: Messenger

string: They pitched in the ground confusedly,
speaker: Messenger

string: To keep the horsemen off from breaking in.
speaker: Messenger

string: More than three hours the fight continued;
speaker: Messenger

string: Where valiant Talbot above human thought
speaker: Messenger

string: Enacted wonders with his sword and lance:
speaker: Messenger

string: Hundreds he sent to hell, and none durst stand him;
speaker: Messenger

string: Here, there, and every where, enraged he flew:
speaker: Messenger

string: The French exclaim'd, the devil was in arms;
speaker: Messenger

string: All the whole army stood agazed on him:
speaker: Messenger

string: His soldiers spying his undaunted spirit
speaker: Messenger

string: A Talbot! a Talbot! cried out amain
speaker: Messenger

string: And rush'd into the bowels of the battle.
speaker: Messenger

string: Here had the conquest fully been seal'd up,
speaker: Messenger

string: If Sir John Fastolfe had not play'd the coward:
speaker: Messenger

string: He, being in the vaward, placed behind
speaker: Messenger

string: With purpose to relieve and follow them,
speaker: Messenger

string: Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke.
speaker: Messenger

string: Hence grew the general wreck and massacre;
speaker: Messenger

string: Enclosed were they with their enemies:
speaker: Messenger

string: A base Walloon, to win the Dauphin's grace,
speaker: Messenger

string: Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back,
speaker: Messenger

string: Whom all France with their chief assembled strength
speaker: Messenger

string: Durst not presume to look once in the face.
speaker: Messenger

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Is Talbot slain? then I will slay myself,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: For living idly here in pomp and ease,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Unto his dastard foemen is betray'd.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: O no, he lives; but is took prisoner,
speaker: Messenger

string: And Lord Scales with him and Lord Hungerford:
speaker: Messenger

string: Most of the rest slaughter'd or took likewise.
speaker: Messenger

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: His ransom there is none but I shall pay:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: I'll hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: His crown shall be the ransom of my friend;
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Four of their lords I'll change for one of ours.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Farewell, my masters; to my task will I;
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: To keep our great Saint George's feast withal:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Whose bloody deeds shall make all Europe quake.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: So you had need; for Orleans is besieged;
speaker: Messenger

string: The English army is grown weak and faint:
speaker: Messenger

string: The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply,
speaker: Messenger

string: And hardly keeps his men from mutiny,
speaker: Messenger

string: Since they, so few, watch such a multitude.
speaker: Messenger

string: EXETER
speaker: EXETER

string: Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn,
speaker: EXETER

string: Either to quell the Dauphin utterly,
speaker: EXETER

string: Or bring him in obedience to your yoke.
speaker: EXETER

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: I do remember it; and here take my leave,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: To go about my preparation.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Exit
GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I'll to the Tower with all the haste I can,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To view the artillery and munition;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And then I will proclaim young Henry king.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Exit
EXETER
speaker: EXETER

string: To Eltham will I, where the young king is,
speaker: EXETER

string: Being ordain'd his special governor,
speaker: EXETER

string: And for his safety there I'll best devise.
speaker: EXETER

string: Exit
BISHOP
speaker: EXETER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Each hath his place and function to attend:
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: I am left out; for me nothing remains.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: But long I will not be Jack out of office:
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: The king from Eltham I intend to steal
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Exeunt
SCENE II. France. Before Orleans.
Sound a flourish. Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, marching with drum and Soldiers
CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens
speaker: CHARLES

string: So in the earth, to this day is not known:
speaker: CHARLES

string: Late did he shine upon the English side;
speaker: CHARLES

string: Now we are victors; upon us he smiles.
speaker: CHARLES

string: What towns of any moment but we have?
speaker: CHARLES

string: At pleasure here we lie near Orleans;
speaker: CHARLES

string: Otherwhiles the famish'd English, like pale ghosts,
speaker: CHARLES

string: Faintly besiege us one hour in a month.
speaker: CHARLES

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: They want their porridge and their fat bull-beeves:
speaker: ALENCON

string: Either they must be dieted like mules
speaker: ALENCON

string: And have their provender tied to their mouths
speaker: ALENCON

string: Or piteous they will look, like drowned mice.
speaker: ALENCON

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Let's raise the siege: why live we idly here?
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear:
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Remaineth none but mad-brain'd Salisbury;
speaker: REIGNIER

string: And he may well in fretting spend his gall,
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Nor men nor money hath he to make war.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Sound, sound alarum! we will rush on them.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Now for the honour of the forlorn French!
speaker: CHARLES

string: Him I forgive my death that killeth me
speaker: CHARLES

string: When he sees me go back one foot or fly.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Exeunt
Here alarum; they are beaten back by the English with great loss. Re-enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER
CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Who ever saw the like? what men have I!
speaker: CHARLES

string: Dogs! cowards! dastards! I would ne'er have fled,
speaker: CHARLES

string: But that they left me 'midst my enemies.
speaker: CHARLES

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Salisbury is a desperate homicide;
speaker: REIGNIER

string: He fighteth as one weary of his life.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: The other lords, like lions wanting food,
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Do rush upon us as their hungry prey.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: Froissart, a countryman of ours, records,
speaker: ALENCON

string: England all Olivers and Rowlands bred,
speaker: ALENCON

string: During the time Edward the Third did reign.
speaker: ALENCON

string: More truly now may this be verified;
speaker: ALENCON

string: For none but Samsons and Goliases
speaker: ALENCON

string: It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten!
speaker: ALENCON

string: Lean, raw-boned rascals! who would e'er suppose
speaker: ALENCON

string: They had such courage and audacity?
speaker: ALENCON

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Let's leave this town; for they are hare-brain'd slaves,
speaker: CHARLES

string: And hunger will enforce them to be more eager:
speaker: CHARLES

string: Of old I know them; rather with their teeth
speaker: CHARLES

string: The walls they'll tear down than forsake the siege.
speaker: CHARLES

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: I think, by some odd gimmors or device
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Their arms are set like clocks, stiff to strike on;
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Else ne'er could they hold out so as they do.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: By my consent, we'll even let them alone.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: Be it so.
speaker: ALENCON

string: Enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS
BASTARD OF ORLEANS
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Where's the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him.
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Bastard of Orleans, thrice welcome to us.
speaker: CHARLES

string: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Methinks your looks are sad, your cheer appall'd:
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence?
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Be not dismay'd, for succor is at hand:
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: A holy maid hither with me I bring,
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Which by a vision sent to her from heaven
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Ordained is to raise this tedious siege
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: And drive the English forth the bounds of France.
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: The spirit of deep prophecy she hath,
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Exceeding the nine sibyls of old Rome:
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: What's past and what's to come she can descry.
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Speak, shall I call her in? Believe my words,
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: For they are certain and unfallible.
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Go, call her in.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Exit BASTARD OF ORLEANS
But first, to try her skill,
speaker: CHARLES

string: Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place:
speaker: CHARLES

string: Question her proudly; let thy looks be stern:
speaker: CHARLES

string: By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Re-enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, with JOAN LA PUCELLE
REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Fair maid, is't thou wilt do these wondrous feats?
speaker: REIGNIER

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Reignier, is't thou that thinkest to beguile me?
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Where is the Dauphin? Come, come from behind;
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: I know thee well, though never seen before.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Be not amazed, there's nothing hid from me:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: In private will I talk with thee apart.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Stand back, you lords, and give us leave awhile.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: She takes upon her bravely at first dash.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Dauphin, I am by birth a shepherd's daughter,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: My wit untrain'd in any kind of art.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Heaven and our Lady gracious hath it pleased
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: To shine on my contemptible estate:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Lo, whilst I waited on my tender lambs,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And to sun's parching heat display'd my cheeks,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: God's mother deigned to appear to me
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And in a vision full of majesty
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Will'd me to leave my base vocation
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And free my country from calamity:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Her aid she promised and assured success:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: In complete glory she reveal'd herself;
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And, whereas I was black and swart before,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: With those clear rays which she infused on me
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: That beauty am I bless'd with which you see.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Ask me what question thou canst possible,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And I will answer unpremeditated:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: My courage try by combat, if thou darest,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And thou shalt find that I exceed my sex.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Resolve on this, thou shalt be fortunate,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: If thou receive me for thy warlike mate.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Thou hast astonish'd me with thy high terms:
speaker: CHARLES

string: Only this proof I'll of thy valour make,
speaker: CHARLES

string: In single combat thou shalt buckle with me,
speaker: CHARLES

string: And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true;
speaker: CHARLES

string: Otherwise I renounce all confidence.
speaker: CHARLES

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: I am prepared: here is my keen-edged sword,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Deck'd with five flower-de-luces on each side;
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: The which at Touraine, in Saint Katharine's
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: churchyard,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Out of a great deal of old iron I chose forth.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Then come, o' God's name; I fear no woman.
speaker: CHARLES

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And while I live, I'll ne'er fly from a man.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Here they fight, and JOAN LA PUCELLE overcomes
CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Stay, stay thy hands! thou art an Amazon
speaker: CHARLES

string: And fightest with the sword of Deborah.
speaker: CHARLES

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Christ's mother helps me, else I were too weak.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Whoe'er helps thee, 'tis thou that must help me:
speaker: CHARLES

string: Impatiently I burn with thy desire;
speaker: CHARLES

string: My heart and hands thou hast at once subdued.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Excellent Pucelle, if thy name be so,
speaker: CHARLES

string: Let me thy servant and not sovereign be:
speaker: CHARLES

string: 'Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.
speaker: CHARLES

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: I must not yield to any rites of love,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: For my profession's sacred from above:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: When I have chased all thy foes from hence,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Then will I think upon a recompense.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.
speaker: CHARLES

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock;
speaker: ALENCON

string: Else ne'er could he so long protract his speech.
speaker: ALENCON

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Shall we disturb him, since he keeps no mean?
speaker: REIGNIER

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: He may mean more than we poor men do know:
speaker: ALENCON

string: These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.
speaker: ALENCON

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: My lord, where are you? what devise you on?
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Shall we give over Orleans, or no?
speaker: REIGNIER

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Why, no, I say, distrustful recreants!
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Fight till the last gasp; I will be your guard.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: What she says I'll confirm: we'll fight it out.
speaker: CHARLES

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Assign'd am I to be the English scourge.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: This night the siege assuredly I'll raise:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Expect Saint Martin's summer, halcyon days,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Since I have entered into these wars.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Glory is like a circle in the water,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Till by broad spreading it disperse to nought.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: With Henry's death the English circle ends;
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Dispersed are the glories it included.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Now am I like that proud insulting ship
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Was Mahomet inspired with a dove?
speaker: CHARLES

string: Thou with an eagle art inspired then.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Helen, the mother of great Constantine,
speaker: CHARLES

string: Nor yet Saint Philip's daughters, were like thee.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Bright star of Venus, fall'n down on the earth,
speaker: CHARLES

string: How may I reverently worship thee enough?
speaker: CHARLES

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: Leave off delays, and let us raise the siege.
speaker: ALENCON

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Woman, do what thou canst to save our honours;
speaker: REIGNIER

string: Drive them from Orleans and be immortalized.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Presently we'll try: come, let's away about it:
speaker: CHARLES

string: No prophet will I trust, if she prove false.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Exeunt
SCENE III. London. Before the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: First Warder

speaker: First Warder

string: First Warder
speaker: First Warder

speaker: First Warder

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: WOODVILE

speaker: WOODVILE

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Stand back, thou manifest conspirator,

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Thou that givest whores indulgences to sin:

string: I'll canvass thee in thy broad cardinal's hat,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: If thou proceed in this thy insolence.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Nay, stand thou back, I will not budge a foot:
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I will not slay thee, but I'll drive thee back:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Draw, men, for all this privileged place;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Blue coats to tawny coats. Priest, beware your beard,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I mean to tug it and to cuff you soundly:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Under my feet I stamp thy cardinal's hat:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: In spite of pope or dignities of church,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the pope.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Winchester goose, I cry, a rope! a rope!
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Thee I'll chase hence, thou wolf in sheep's array.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Out, tawny coats! out, scarlet hypocrite!
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Here GLOUCESTER's men beat out BISHOP OF  WINCHESTER's men, and enter in the hurly- burly the Mayor of London and his Officers

speaker: Mayor

string: Fie, lords! that you, being supreme magistrates,
speaker: Mayor

string: Thus contumeliously should break the peace!
speaker: Mayor

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Peace, mayor! thou know'st little of my wrongs:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Here's Beaufort, that regards nor God nor king,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Hath here distrain'd the Tower to his use.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Here's Gloucester, a foe to citizens,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: One that still motions war and never peace,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: O'ercharging your free purses with large fines,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Because he is protector of the realm,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: To crown himself king and suppress the prince.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I will not answer thee with words, but blows.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Here they skirmish again
Mayor
speaker: Mayor

string: Naught rests for me in this tumultuous strife
speaker: Mayor

speaker: Mayor

string: Come, officer; as loud as e'er thou canst,
speaker: Mayor

string: Cry.
speaker: Mayor

string: Officer
speaker: Officer

speaker: Officer

string: against God's peace and the king's, we charge and
speaker: Officer

string: command you, in his highness' name, to repair to
speaker: Officer

string: your several dwelling-places; and not to wear,
speaker: Officer

string: handle, or use any sword, weapon, or dagger,
speaker: Officer

string: henceforward, upon pain of death.
speaker: Officer

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Cardinal, I'll be no breaker of the law:

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: OF WINCHESTER

speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Mayor
speaker: Mayor

string: I'll call for clubs, if you will not away.
speaker: Mayor

string: This cardinal's more haughty than the devil.
speaker: Mayor

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BISHOP
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: For I intend to have it ere long.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

Mayor
speaker: Mayor

string: See the coast clear'd, and then we will depart.
speaker: Mayor

string: Good God, these nobles should such stomachs bear!
speaker: Mayor

string: I myself fight not once in forty year.
speaker: Mayor

SCENE IV. Orleans.
Enter, on the walls, a Master Gunner and his Boy
Master-Gunner	Sirrah, thou know'st how Orleans is besieged,
speaker: Mayor

string: And how the English have the suburbs won.
speaker: Mayor

string: Boy
speaker: Boy

string: Father, I know; and oft have shot at them,
speaker: Boy

string: Howe'er unfortunate I miss'd my aim.
speaker: Boy

speaker: Boy

string: Chief master-gunner am I of this town;
speaker: Boy

string: Something I must do to procure me grace.
speaker: Boy

string: The prince's espials have informed me
speaker: Boy

string: How the English, in the suburbs close intrench'd,
speaker: Boy

string: Wont, through a secret grate of iron bars
speaker: Boy

string: In yonder tower, to overpeer the city,
speaker: Boy

string: And thence discover how with most advantage
speaker: Boy

string: They may vex us with shot, or with assault.
speaker: Boy

string: To intercept this inconvenience,
speaker: Boy

string: A piece of ordnance 'gainst it I have placed;
speaker: Boy

string: And even these three days have I watch'd,
speaker: Boy

string: If I could see them.
speaker: Boy

string: Now do thou watch, for I can stay no longer.
speaker: Boy

string: If thou spy'st any, run and bring me word;
speaker: Boy

string: And thou shalt find me at the governor's.
speaker: Boy

string: Exit
Boy
speaker: Boy

string: Father, I warrant you; take you no care;
speaker: Boy

string: I'll never trouble you, if I may spy them.
speaker: Boy

string: Exit

SALISBURY
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Talbot, my life, my joy, again return'd!
speaker: SALISBURY

string: How wert thou handled being prisoner?
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Or by what means got'st thou to be released?
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Discourse, I prithee, on this turret's top.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: The Duke of Bedford had a prisoner
speaker: TALBOT

string: Call'd the brave Lord Ponton de Santrailles;
speaker: TALBOT

string: For him was I exchanged and ransomed.
speaker: TALBOT

string: But with a baser man of arms by far
speaker: TALBOT

string: Once in contempt they would have barter'd me:
speaker: TALBOT

string: Which I, disdaining, scorn'd; and craved death,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Rather than I would be so vile esteem'd.
speaker: TALBOT

string: In fine, redeem'd I was as I desired.
speaker: TALBOT

string: But, O! the treacherous Fastolfe wounds my heart,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Whom with my bare fists I would execute,
speaker: TALBOT

string: If I now had him brought into my power.
speaker: TALBOT

string: SALISBURY
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Yet tell'st thou not how thou wert entertain'd.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: With scoffs and scorns and contumelious taunts.
speaker: TALBOT

string: In open market-place produced they me,
speaker: TALBOT

string: To be a public spectacle to all:
speaker: TALBOT

string: Here, said they, is the terror of the French,
speaker: TALBOT

string: The scarecrow that affrights our children so.
speaker: TALBOT

string: Then broke I from the officers that led me,
speaker: TALBOT

string: And with my nails digg'd stones out of the ground,
speaker: TALBOT

string: To hurl at the beholders of my shame:
speaker: TALBOT

string: My grisly countenance made others fly;
speaker: TALBOT

string: None durst come near for fear of sudden death.
speaker: TALBOT

string: In iron walls they deem'd me not secure;
speaker: TALBOT

string: So great fear of my name 'mongst them was spread,
speaker: TALBOT

string: That they supposed I could rend bars of steel,
speaker: TALBOT

string: And spurn in pieces posts of adamant:
speaker: TALBOT

string: Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had,
speaker: TALBOT

string: That walked about me every minute-while;
speaker: TALBOT

string: And if I did but stir out of my bed,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Ready they were to shoot me to the heart.
speaker: TALBOT

string: Enter the Boy with a linstock
SALISBURY
speaker: SALISBURY

string: I grieve to hear what torments you endured,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: But we will be revenged sufficiently
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Now it is supper-time in Orleans:
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Here, through this grate, I count each one
speaker: SALISBURY

string: and view the Frenchmen how they fortify:
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Let us look in; the sight will much delight thee.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Sir Thomas Gargrave, and Sir William Glansdale,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Let me have your express opinions
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Where is best place to make our battery next.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: GARGRAVE
speaker: GARGRAVE

string: I think, at the north gate; for there stand lords.
speaker: GARGRAVE

string: GLANSDALE
speaker: GLANSDALE

string: And I, here, at the bulwark of the bridge.
speaker: GLANSDALE

string: TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: Or with light skirmishes enfeebled.
speaker: TALBOT

SALISBURY
speaker: SALISBURY

string: O Lord, have mercy on us, wretched sinners!
speaker: SALISBURY

string: GARGRAVE
speaker: GARGRAVE

string: O Lord, have mercy on me, woful man!
speaker: GARGRAVE

string: TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: What chance is this that suddenly hath cross'd us?
speaker: TALBOT

string: Speak, Salisbury; at least, if thou canst speak:
speaker: TALBOT

string: How farest thou, mirror of all martial men?
speaker: TALBOT

string: One of thy eyes and thy cheek's side struck off!
speaker: TALBOT

string: Accursed tower! accursed fatal hand
speaker: TALBOT

string: That hath contrived this woful tragedy!
speaker: TALBOT

string: In thirteen battles Salisbury o'ercame;
speaker: TALBOT

string: Henry the Fifth he first train'd to the wars;
speaker: TALBOT

string: Whilst any trump did sound, or drum struck up,
speaker: TALBOT

string: His sword did ne'er leave striking in the field.
speaker: TALBOT

string: Yet livest thou, Salisbury? though thy speech doth fail,
speaker: TALBOT

string: One eye thou hast, to look to heaven for grace:
speaker: TALBOT

string: The sun with one eye vieweth all the world.
speaker: TALBOT

string: Heaven, be thou gracious to none alive,
speaker: TALBOT

string: If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands!
speaker: TALBOT

string: Bear hence his body; I will help to bury it.
speaker: TALBOT

string: Sir Thomas Gargrave, hast thou any life?
speaker: TALBOT

string: Speak unto Talbot; nay, look up to him.
speaker: TALBOT

string: Salisbury, cheer thy spirit with this comfort;
speaker: TALBOT

string: Thou shalt not die whiles--
speaker: TALBOT

string: He beckons with his hand and smiles on me.
speaker: TALBOT

string: As who should say 'When I am dead and gone,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Remember to avenge me on the French.'
speaker: TALBOT

string: Plantagenet, I will; and like thee, Nero,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Play on the lute, beholding the towns burn:
speaker: TALBOT

string: Wretched shall France be only in my name.
speaker: TALBOT

string: Here an alarum, and it thunders and lightens
What stir is this? what tumult's in the heavens?
speaker: TALBOT

string: Whence cometh this alarum and the noise?
speaker: TALBOT

Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: My lord, my lord, the French have gathered head:
speaker: Messenger

string: The Dauphin, with one Joan la Pucelle join'd,
speaker: Messenger

speaker: Messenger

speaker: Messenger

string: Here SALISBURY lifteth himself up and groans
TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: It irks his heart he cannot be revenged.
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: Pucelle or puzzel, dolphin or dogfish,
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

SCENE V. The same.
Here an alarum again: and TALBOT pursueth the  DAUPHIN, and driveth him: then enter JOAN LA PUCELLE, driving Englishmen before her, and exit after them then re-enter TALBOT
TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: Where is my strength, my valour, and my force?
speaker: TALBOT

string: Our English troops retire, I cannot stay them:
speaker: TALBOT

string: A woman clad in armour chaseth them.
speaker: TALBOT

Here, here she comes. I'll have a bout with thee;
speaker: TALBOT

string: Devil or devil's dam, I'll conjure thee:
speaker: TALBOT

string: Blood will I draw on thee, thou art a witch,

speaker: TALBOT

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Come, come, 'tis only I that must disgrace thee.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Here they fight
TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: I must go victual Orleans forthwith.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

O'ertake me, if thou canst; I scorn thy strength.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Go, go, cheer up thy hungry-starved men;
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Help Salisbury to make his testament:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Exit
TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: My thoughts are whirled like a potter's wheel;
speaker: TALBOT

string: I know not where I am, nor what I do;
speaker: TALBOT

string: A witch, by fear, not force, like Hannibal,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Drives back our troops and conquers as she lists:
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: Are from their hives and houses driven away.
speaker: TALBOT

string: They call'd us for our fierceness English dogs;
speaker: TALBOT

string: Now, like to whelps, we crying run away.
speaker: TALBOT

Hark, countrymen! either renew the fight,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Or tear the lions out of England's coat;
speaker: TALBOT

string: Renounce your soil, give sheep in lions' stead:
speaker: TALBOT

string: Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Or horse or oxen from the leopard,
speaker: TALBOT

string: As you fly from your oft-subdued slaves.
speaker: TALBOT

string: Alarum. Here another skirmish
It will not be: retire into your trenches:
speaker: TALBOT

string: You all consented unto Salisbury's death,
speaker: TALBOT

string: For none would strike a stroke in his revenge.
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: In spite of us or aught that we could do.
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

string: France, triumph in thy glorious prophetess!
speaker: CHARLES

speaker: REIGNIER

speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

string: Shall in procession sing her endless praise.
speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

string: Transported shall be at high festivals
speaker: CHARLES

string: Before the kings and queens of France.
speaker: CHARLES

string: No longer on Saint Denis will we cry,
speaker: CHARLES

string: But Joan la Pucelle shall be France's saint.
speaker: CHARLES

string: Come in, and let us banquet royally,
speaker: CHARLES

string: After this golden day of victory.
speaker: CHARLES

speaker: TALBOT

string: And as his father here was conqueror,
speaker: TALBOT

string: As sure as in this late-betrayed town
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: My vows are equal partners with thy vows.
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: But, ere we go, regard this dying prince,
speaker: TALBOT

string: The valiant Duke of Bedford. Come, my lord,
speaker: TALBOT

string: We will bestow you in some better place,
speaker: TALBOT

string: Fitter for sickness and for crazy age.
speaker: TALBOT

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Lord Talbot, do not so dishonour me:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Here will I sit before the walls of Rouen
speaker: BEDFORD

string: And will be partner of your weal or woe.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Courageous Bedford, let us now persuade you.
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Not to be gone from hence; for once I read
speaker: BEDFORD

string: That stout Pendragon in his litter sick
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Came to the field and vanquished his foes:
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Methinks I should revive the soldiers' hearts,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Because I ever found them as myself.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: Undaunted spirit in a dying breast!
speaker: TALBOT

string: Then be it so: heavens keep old Bedford safe!
speaker: TALBOT

string: And now no more ado, brave Burgundy,
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: And set upon our boasting enemy.
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: Captain

speaker: Captain

string: FASTOLFE
speaker: FASTOLFE

speaker: FASTOLFE

speaker: Captain

speaker: Captain

string: FASTOLFE
speaker: FASTOLFE

speaker: FASTOLFE

Captain

BEDFORD
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Now, quiet soul, depart when heaven please,
speaker: BEDFORD

string: For I have seen our enemies' overthrow.
speaker: BEDFORD

string: What is the trust or strength of foolish man?
speaker: BEDFORD

string: They that of late were daring with their scoffs
speaker: BEDFORD

string: Are glad and fain by flight to save themselves.
speaker: BEDFORD

TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: Lost, and recover'd in a day again!
speaker: TALBOT

string: This is a double honour, Burgundy:
speaker: TALBOT

string: Yet heavens have glory for this victory!
speaker: TALBOT

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Warlike and martial Talbot, Burgundy
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Enshrines thee in his heart and there erects
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Thy noble deeds as valour's monuments.
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

string: Thanks, gentle duke. But where is Pucelle now?
speaker: TALBOT

string: I think her old familiar is asleep:
speaker: TALBOT

string: Now where's the Bastard's braves, and Charles his gleeks?
speaker: TALBOT

string: What, all amort? Rouen hangs her head for grief
speaker: TALBOT

string: That such a valiant company are fled.
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: Placing therein some expert officers,
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: What wills Lord Talbot pleaseth Burgundy.
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: TALBOT
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

string: The noble Duke of Bedford late deceased,
speaker: TALBOT

string: But see his exequies fulfill'd in Rouen:
speaker: TALBOT

string: A braver soldier never couched lance,
speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

SCENE III. The plains near Rouen.
Enter CHARLES, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, JOAN LA PUCELLE, and forces
JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Dismay not, princes, at this accident,

string: Nor grieve that Rouen is so recovered:

string: Care is no cure, but rather corrosive,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: If Dauphin and the rest will be but ruled.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: We have been guided by thee hitherto,
speaker: CHARLES

string: And of thy cunning had no diffidence:
speaker: CHARLES

string: One sudden foil shall never breed distrust.
speaker: CHARLES

string: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: Search out thy wit for secret policies,

string: And we will make thee famous through the world.
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: We'll set thy statue in some holy place,
speaker: ALENCON

string: And have thee reverenced like a blessed saint:
speaker: ALENCON

string: Employ thee then, sweet virgin, for our good.
speaker: ALENCON

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Then thus it must be; this doth Joan devise:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: By fair persuasions mix'd with sugar'd words
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: We will entice the Duke of Burgundy
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: To leave the Talbot and to follow us.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Ay, marry, sweeting, if we could do that,
speaker: CHARLES

string: France were no place for Henry's warriors;
speaker: CHARLES

string: Nor should that nation boast it so with us,
speaker: CHARLES

string: But be extirped from our provinces.
speaker: CHARLES

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

speaker: ALENCON

speaker: ALENCON

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: To bring this matter to the wished end.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Their powers are marching unto Paris-ward.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And all the troops of English after him.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: French march. Enter BURGUNDY and forces
Now in the rearward comes the duke and his:

string: Fortune in favour makes him lag behind.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Summon a parley; we will talk with him.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: A parley with the Duke of Burgundy!
speaker: CHARLES

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Who craves a parley with the Burgundy?
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: The princely Charles of France, thy countryman.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: What say'st thou, Charles? for I am marching hence.
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Speak, Pucelle, and enchant him with thy words.
speaker: CHARLES

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Brave Burgundy, undoubted hope of France!
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Stay, let thy humble handmaid speak to thee.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Speak on; but be not over-tedious.
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Look on thy country, look on fertile France,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And see the cities and the towns defaced
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: By wasting ruin of the cruel foe.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: As looks the mother on her lowly babe
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: When death doth close his tender dying eyes,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: See, see the pining malady of France;
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Behold the wounds, the most unnatural wounds,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Which thou thyself hast given her woful breast.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: O, turn thy edged sword another way;
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Strike those that hurt, and hurt not those that help.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: One drop of blood drawn from thy country's bosom
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Should grieve thee more than streams of foreign gore:
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Return thee therefore with a flood of tears,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And wash away thy country's stained spots.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Either she hath bewitch'd me with her words,
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Or nature makes me suddenly relent.
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Besides, all French and France exclaims on thee,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Doubting thy birth and lawful progeny.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Who joint'st thou with but with a lordly nation
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: That will not trust thee but for profit's sake?
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: When Talbot hath set footing once in France
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And fashion'd thee that instrument of ill,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Who then but English Henry will be lord
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And thou be thrust out like a fugitive?
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Call we to mind, and mark but this for proof,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Was not the Duke of Orleans thy foe?
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And was he not in England prisoner?
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: But when they heard he was thine enemy,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: They set him free without his ransom paid,
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: In spite of Burgundy and all his friends.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: See, then, thou fight'st against thy countrymen
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: And joint'st with them will be thy slaughtermen.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: Come, come, return; return, thou wandering lord:

string: Charles and the rest will take thee in their arms.
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: BURGUNDY
speaker: BURGUNDY

string: I am vanquished; these haughty words of hers
speaker: BURGUNDY

speaker: BURGUNDY

speaker: BURGUNDY

string: Forgive me, country, and sweet countrymen,
speaker: BURGUNDY

speaker: BURGUNDY

speaker: BURGUNDY

string: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES

string: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: And doth deserve a coronet of gold.
speaker: ALENCON

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Now let us on, my lords, and join our powers,
speaker: CHARLES

string: And seek how we may prejudice the foe.
speaker: CHARLES

Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, YORK, SUFFOLK, SOMERSET, WARWICK,  EXETER, VERNON	BASSET, and others. To them with his Soldiers, TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: KING HENRY VI

BASSET

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: TALBOT

speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: With letters of commission from the king.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: For know, my lords, the states of Christendom,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Moved with remorse of these outrageous broils,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Have earnestly implored a general peace
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Betwixt our nation and the aspiring French;
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: And here at hand the Dauphin and his train
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Approacheth, to confer about some matter.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: YORK
speaker: YORK

string: Is all our travail turn'd to this effect?
speaker: YORK

string: After the slaughter of so many peers,
speaker: YORK

string: So many captains, gentlemen and soldiers,
speaker: YORK

string: That in this quarrel have been overthrown
speaker: YORK

string: And sold their bodies for their country's benefit,
speaker: YORK

string: Shall we at last conclude effeminate peace?
speaker: YORK

string: Have we not lost most part of all the towns,
speaker: YORK

string: By treason, falsehood and by treachery,
speaker: YORK

string: Our great progenitors had conquered?
speaker: YORK

string: O Warwick, Warwick! I foresee with grief
speaker: YORK

string: The utter loss of all the realm of France.
speaker: YORK

string: WARWICK
speaker: WARWICK

string: Be patient, York: if we conclude a peace,
speaker: WARWICK

string: It shall be with such strict and severe covenants
speaker: WARWICK

string: As little shall the Frenchmen gain thereby.
speaker: WARWICK

string: Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, BASTARD OF ORLEANS, REIGNIER, and others
CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: Since, lords of England, it is thus agreed
speaker: CHARLES

string: That peaceful truce shall be proclaim'd in France,
speaker: CHARLES

string: We come to be informed by yourselves
speaker: CHARLES

string: What the conditions of that league must be.
speaker: CHARLES

string: YORK
speaker: YORK

string: Speak, Winchester; for boiling choler chokes
speaker: YORK

string: The hollow passage of my poison'd voice,
speaker: YORK

string: By sight of these our baleful enemies.
speaker: YORK

string: CARDINAL
speaker: YORK

string: OF WINCHESTER
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Charles, and the rest, it is enacted thus:
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: That, in regard King Henry gives consent,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Of mere compassion and of lenity,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: To ease your country of distressful war,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: And suffer you to breathe in fruitful peace,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: You shall become true liegemen to his crown:
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: And Charles, upon condition thou wilt swear
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: To pay him tribute, submit thyself,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: Thou shalt be placed as viceroy under him,
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: And still enjoy thy regal dignity.
speaker: OF WINCHESTER

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: Must he be then as shadow of himself?
speaker: ALENCON

string: Adorn his temples with a coronet,
speaker: ALENCON

string: And yet, in substance and authority,
speaker: ALENCON

string: Retain but privilege of a private man?
speaker: ALENCON

string: This proffer is absurd and reasonless.
speaker: ALENCON

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: 'Tis known already that I am possess'd
speaker: CHARLES

string: With more than half the Gallian territories,
speaker: CHARLES

string: And therein reverenced for their lawful king:
speaker: CHARLES

string: Shall I, for lucre of the rest unvanquish'd,
speaker: CHARLES

string: Detract so much from that prerogative,
speaker: CHARLES

string: As to be call'd but viceroy of the whole?
speaker: CHARLES

string: No, lord ambassador, I'll rather keep
speaker: CHARLES

string: That which I have than, coveting for more,
speaker: CHARLES

string: Be cast from possibility of all.
speaker: CHARLES

string: YORK
speaker: YORK

string: Insulting Charles! hast thou by secret means
speaker: YORK

string: Used intercession to obtain a league,
speaker: YORK

string: And, now the matter grows to compromise,
speaker: YORK

string: Stand'st thou aloof upon comparison?
speaker: YORK

string: Either accept the title thou usurp'st,
speaker: YORK

string: Of benefit proceeding from our king
speaker: YORK

string: And not of any challenge of desert,
speaker: YORK

string: Or we will plague thee with incessant wars.
speaker: YORK

string: REIGNIER
speaker: REIGNIER

string: My lord, you do not well in obstinacy
speaker: REIGNIER

string: To cavil in the course of this contract:
speaker: REIGNIER

string: If once it be neglected, ten to one
speaker: REIGNIER

string: We shall not find like opportunity.
speaker: REIGNIER

string: ALENCON
speaker: ALENCON

string: To say the truth, it is your policy
speaker: ALENCON

string: To save your subjects from such massacre
speaker: ALENCON

string: And ruthless slaughters as are daily seen
speaker: ALENCON

string: By our proceeding in hostility;
speaker: ALENCON

string: And therefore take this compact of a truce,
speaker: ALENCON

string: Although you break it when your pleasure serves.
speaker: ALENCON

string: WARWICK
speaker: WARWICK

string: How say'st thou, Charles? shall our condition stand?
speaker: WARWICK

string: CHARLES
speaker: CHARLES

string: It shall;
speaker: CHARLES

string: Only reserved, you claim no interest
speaker: CHARLES

string: In any of our towns of garrison.
speaker: CHARLES

string: YORK
speaker: YORK

string: Then swear allegiance to his majesty,
speaker: YORK

string: As thou art knight, never to disobey
speaker: YORK

string: Nor be rebellious to the crown of England,
speaker: YORK

string: Thou, nor thy nobles, to the crown of England.
speaker: YORK

string: So, now dismiss your army when ye please:
speaker: YORK

string: Hang up your ensign, let your drums be still,
speaker: YORK

string: For here we entertain a solemn peace.
speaker: YORK

string: Exeunt
SCENE V. London. The palace.
Enter SUFFOLK in conference with KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER and EXETER
KING HENRY VI
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Your wondrous rare description, noble earl,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Of beauteous Margaret hath astonish'd me:
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Her virtues graced with external gifts
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Do breed love's settled passions in my heart:
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: And like as rigor of tempestuous gusts
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Provokes the mightiest hulk against the tide,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: So am I driven by breath of her renown
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Either to suffer shipwreck or arrive
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Where I may have fruition of her love.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: SUFFOLK
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Tush, my good lord, this superficial tale
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Is but a preface of her worthy praise;
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: The chief perfections of that lovely dame
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Had I sufficient skill to utter them,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Would make a volume of enticing lines,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Able to ravish any dull conceit:
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: And, which is more, she is not so divine,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: So full-replete with choice of all delights,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: But with as humble lowliness of mind
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: She is content to be at your command;
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Command, I mean, of virtuous chaste intents,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: To love and honour Henry as her lord.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: KING HENRY VI
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: And otherwise will Henry ne'er presume.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Therefore, my lord protector, give consent
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: That Margaret may be England's royal queen.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: So should I give consent to flatter sin.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: You know, my lord, your highness is betroth'd
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Unto another lady of esteem:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: How shall we then dispense with that contract,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And not deface your honour with reproach?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: SUFFOLK
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: As doth a ruler with unlawful oaths;
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Or one that, at a triumph having vow'd
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: To try his strength, forsaketh yet the lists
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: By reason of his adversary's odds:
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: A poor earl's daughter is unequal odds,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: And therefore may be broke without offence.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Why, what, I pray, is Margaret more than that?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Her father is no better than an earl,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Although in glorious titles he excel.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: SUFFOLK
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Yes, lord, her father is a king,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: The King of Naples and Jerusalem;
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: And of such great authority in France
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: As his alliance will confirm our peace
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: And keep the Frenchmen in allegiance.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And so the Earl of Armagnac may do,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Because he is near kinsman unto Charles.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: EXETER
speaker: EXETER

string: Beside, his wealth doth warrant a liberal dower,
speaker: EXETER

string: Where Reignier sooner will receive than give.
speaker: EXETER

string: SUFFOLK
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: A dower, my lords! disgrace not so your king,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: That he should be so abject, base and poor,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: To choose for wealth and not for perfect love.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Henry is able to enrich his queen
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: And not seek a queen to make him rich:
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: So worthless peasants bargain for their wives,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: As market-men for oxen, sheep, or horse.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Marriage is a matter of more worth
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Than to be dealt in by attorneyship;
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Not whom we will, but whom his grace affects,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Must be companion of his nuptial bed:
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: And therefore, lords, since he affects her most,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: It most of all these reasons bindeth us,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: In our opinions she should be preferr'd.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: For what is wedlock forced but a hell,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: An age of discord and continual strife?
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Whereas the contrary bringeth bliss,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: And is a pattern of celestial peace.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Whom should we match with Henry, being a king,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: But Margaret, that is daughter to a king?
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Her peerless feature, joined with her birth,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Approves her fit for none but for a king:
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Her valiant courage and undaunted spirit,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: More than in women commonly is seen,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Will answer our hope in issue of a king;
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: For Henry, son unto a conqueror,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Is likely to beget more conquerors,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: If with a lady of so high resolve
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: As is fair Margaret he be link'd in love.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Then yield, my lords; and here conclude with me
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: That Margaret shall be queen, and none but she.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: KING HENRY VI
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Whether it be through force of your report,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: My noble Lord of Suffolk, or for that
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: My tender youth was never yet attaint
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: With any passion of inflaming love,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: I cannot tell; but this I am assured,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: I feel such sharp dissension in my breast,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Such fierce alarums both of hope and fear,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: As I am sick with working of my thoughts.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Take, therefore, shipping; post, my lord, to France;
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Agree to any covenants, and procure
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: That Lady Margaret do vouchsafe to come
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: To cross the seas to England and be crown'd
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: King Henry's faithful and anointed queen:
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: For your expenses and sufficient charge,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Among the people gather up a tenth.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Be gone, I say; for, till you do return,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: I rest perplexed with a thousand cares.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: And you, good uncle, banish all offence:
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: If you do censure me by what you were,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Not what you are, I know it will excuse
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: This sudden execution of my will.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: And so, conduct me where, from company,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: I may revolve and ruminate my grief.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Exit
GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Ay, grief, I fear me, both at first and last.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Exeunt GLOUCESTER and EXETER
SUFFOLK
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Thus Suffolk hath prevail'd; and thus he goes,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: As did the youthful Paris once to Greece,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: With hope to find the like event in love,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: But prosper better than the Trojan did.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Margaret shall now be queen, and rule the king;
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: But I will rule both her, the king and realm.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Exit
